EXECUTIVE SUMMARY



The Helena Montgomery, IN Facility has submitted this updated electronic RMP in compliance with the provisions of the Clean Air Act 112 (r) as codified by the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency at 40 CFR Part 68. Standards codified by the Occupational Safety and Health Administration at 29 CFR 1910.119 are not applicable to the operations at this facility because the Facility is operated as a retail operation and is exempt from the OSHA standards.  However, the OSHA standards at 29 CFR 1910.111, Storage and Handling of Anhydrous Ammonia, are applicable and are included in the Risk Management Program (RMPr) document that is implemented by this Facility.  



This electronic submittal provides conservative estimates of the offsite consequences of an accidental release of anhydrous ammonia from the Facility located approximately 1 mile west of Montgomery, IN at 5070 East 100 North Montgomery, IN 47558.  The electronic RMP summarizes the policies and procedures implemented by the Facility to minimize the likelihood of an accident.  The electronic RMP also summarizes the actions that the Facility has taken to ensure that a response to a release will be implemented in a proper and timely manner.



PURPOSE FOR UPDATING RMP



The Facility is submitting this as a First Time Submittal (i.e. New Facility).  All RMP Facility details are reflected in both the EPA RMP Submit report and the Facility Risk Management Plan Program Document (RMPr).



FACILITY



The Facility is a retail agricultural chemical facility and operates one (1) covered process that includes Storage and Handling of anhydrous ammonia.  Anhydrous ammonia is transported to the Facility via a commercial tanker truck and then transferred to two (2) 30,000-gallon stationary pressure vessels.  The commercial tanker truck operator (Contractor) performs these transfer operations.



The Facility stores the anhydrous ammonia in the on-site stationary pressure vessels and then transfers the anh

ydrous ammonia from the pressure vessels to nurse tanks at point of retail sale to the end user (e.g. the farmer).  This Facility owns and operates (46) 1,450-gallon nurse tanks and (28) 1,000-gallon nurse tanks.  Trained Facility Operators perform the transfer operation in accordance with the RMPr accident prevention program.



OFF-SITE CONSEQUENCE ANALYSIS



Worst case and alternative case consequence analyses were completed for the single covered process that is operated at this Facility. The covered process includes anhydrous ammonia Storage and Handling.  The worst case scenario release for the Retail Facility assumes that all the contents in the largest single storage tank are released.  For this Facility, the largest vessel is a 30,000-gallon stationary pressure vessel.  The release was modeled as if the ammonia tank was punctured on the side at the ground level. The resulting release of ammonia was modeled as a ground level horizontal jet.



The alternative (or more likely to occur) scenario was completed for the storage and handling covered process as well.  The alternative release for the Storage and Handling assumes a 30-second release from a ruptured 3-inch transfer hose caused by an impact from a vehicle or some other source on the liquid ammonia transfer hose during a loading or unloading operation.  Active mitigation considered in this release scenario includes the activation of a backflow check valve, excess flow valves, and electronically activated internal and emergency shutoff valves on the storage tank side of the bulkhead, and operating procedures that the Facility uses to safeguard ammonia transfer operations.



ACCIDENT PREVENTION PROGRAM



The Operations Manager implements the risk management planning process at this Facility.  The Operations Manager is assisted by other Facility staff, as directed.  The Operations Manager is responsible for ensuring that Facility Staff are properly trained in the implementation of the Prevention Program

which includes Safety Information, Hazard Analysis, Operating Procedures, Training, Maintenance, Compliance Audits, Incident Investigations, and Emergency Contingency Plans.



EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM



This is a non-responding Facility.  The Facility has coordinated emergency response activities with its local emergency response agency and local fire department.



FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY



This is a new Facility and no accidents involving anhydrous ammonia have occurred.



CONCLUSION



The Risk Management Plan implemented by the Facility complies with the requirements of the Clean Air Act, Section 112(r).  The RMP will be updated as the Facility adds, deletes, or changes processes.  The Emergency Response Program has been coordinated with the local Fire Department and LEPC.  



NOTE: Sections 4, 5, 6 and 7 of the standard RMP produced by EPA's RMP Submit Program are not applicable to this Facility.
